# Spinal nerve

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

_Spinal nerve_  
---  
[![Spinal
nerve.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Spinal_nerve.svg/250px-
Spinal_nerve.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Spinal_nerve.svg) The formation of the
spinal nerve from the posterior and anterior roots  
Details

**_[Anatomical terms of neuroanatomy](/wiki/Anatomical_terms_of_neuroanatomy
"Anatomical terms of neuroanatomy")_** [[edit on
Wikidata](https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q937076 "d:Q937076")]  
  
A **spinal nerve** is a mixed [nerve](/wiki/Nerve "Nerve"), which carries
motor, sensory, and autonomic signals between the [spinal
cord](/wiki/Spinal_cord "Spinal cord") and the body. In the [human
body](/wiki/Human_body "Human body") there are 31 pairs of spinal nerves, one
on each side of the [vertebral column](/wiki/Vertebral_column "Vertebral
column"). These are grouped into the corresponding
[cervical](/wiki/Cervical_vertebrae "Cervical vertebrae"),
[thoracic](/wiki/Thoracic_vertebrae "Thoracic vertebrae"),
[lumbar](/wiki/Lumbar_vertebrae "Lumbar vertebrae"),
[sacral](/wiki/Sacral_vertebrae "Sacral vertebrae") and
[coccygeal](/wiki/Coccygeal_vertebrae "Coccygeal vertebrae") regions of the
spine.[1] There are eight pairs of **cervical nerves** , twelve pairs of
**thoracic nerves** , five pairs of **lumbar nerves** , five pairs of **sacral
nerves** , and one pair of **coccygeal nerves**. The spinal nerves are part of
the [peripheral nervous system](/wiki/Peripheral_nervous_system "Peripheral
nervous system").

## Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Spinal_nerve&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Structure")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Gray675.png/240px-
Gray675.png)](/wiki/File:Gray675.png)

[](/wiki/File:Gray675.png "Enlarge")

Spinal nerve

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Cervical_vertebra_english.png/240px-
Cervical_vertebra_english.png)](/wiki/File:Cervical_vertebra_english.png)

[](/wiki/File:Cervical_vertebra_english.png "Enlarge")

Typical spinal nerve location

Each spinal nerve is formed from the combination of [nerve fibers](/wiki/Axon
"Axon") from its [dorsal](/wiki/Dorsal_root_of_spinal_nerve "Dorsal root of
spinal nerve") and [ventral roots](/wiki/Ventral_root_of_spinal_nerve "Ventral
root of spinal nerve"). The dorsal root is the
[afferent](/wiki/Afferent_nerve_fiber "Afferent nerve fiber") sensory root and
carries sensory information to the brain. The ventral root is the
[efferent](/wiki/Efferent_nerve_fiber "Efferent nerve fiber") motor root and
carries motor information from the brain. The spinal nerve emerges from the
spinal column through an opening ([intervertebral
foramen](/wiki/Intervertebral_foramen "Intervertebral foramen")) between
adjacent vertebrae. This is true for all spinal nerves except for the first
spinal nerve pair (C1), which emerges between the [occipital
bone](/wiki/Occipital_bone "Occipital bone") and the
[atlas](/wiki/Atlas_\(anatomy\) "Atlas \(anatomy\)") (the first vertebra).
Thus the cervical nerves are numbered by the vertebra below, except spinal
nerve C8, which exists below vertebra C7 and above vertebra T1. The thoracic,
lumbar, and sacral nerves are then numbered by the vertebra above. In the case
of a [lumbarized](/wiki/Lumbar_vertebrae#Variation "Lumbar vertebrae") S1
vertebra (aka L6) or a [sacralized](/wiki/Lumbar_vertebrae#Variation "Lumbar
vertebrae") L5 vertebra, the nerves are typically still counted to L5 and the
next nerve is S1.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Gray799.svg/300px-
Gray799.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Gray799.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Gray799.svg "Enlarge")

Scheme showing structure of a typical spinal nerve  
1\. [Somatic efferent](/wiki/General_somatic_efferent_fibers "General somatic
efferent fibers").  
2\. [Somatic afferent](/wiki/General_somatic_afferent_fibers "General somatic
afferent fibers").  
3,4,5. [Sympathetic efferent](/wiki/General_visceral_efferent_fibers "General
visceral efferent fibers").  
6,7. [Sympathetic afferent](/wiki/General_visceral_afferent_fibers "General
visceral afferent fibers")

Outside the vertebral column, the nerve divides into branches. The [dorsal
ramus](/wiki/Dorsal_ramus_of_spinal_nerve "Dorsal ramus of spinal nerve")
contains nerves that serve the posterior portions of the trunk carrying
visceral motor, somatic motor, and somatic sensory information to and from the
skin and muscles of the back ([epaxial muscles](/wiki/Epaxial_muscles "Epaxial
muscles")). The [ventral ramus](/wiki/Ventral_ramus "Ventral ramus") contains
nerves that serve the remaining anterior parts of the trunk and the upper and
lower limbs ([hypaxial muscles](/wiki/Hypaxial_muscles "Hypaxial muscles"))
carrying visceral motor, somatic motor, and sensory information to and from
the ventrolateral body surface, structures in the body wall, and the limbs.
The [meningeal branches (recurrent meningeal or sinuvertebral
nerves)](/wiki/Meningeal_branches_of_spinal_nerve "Meningeal branches of
spinal nerve") branch from the spinal nerve and re-enter the intervertebral
foramen to serve the ligaments, dura, blood vessels, intervertebral discs,
facet joints, and periosteum of the vertebrae. The [rami
communicantes](/wiki/Rami_communicantes "Rami communicantes") contain
autonomic nerves that serve visceral functions carrying visceral motor and
sensory information to and from the visceral organs.

Some anterior rami merge with adjacent anterior rami to form a [nerve
plexus](/wiki/Nerve_plexus "Nerve plexus"), a network of interconnecting
nerves. Nerves emerging from a plexus contain fibers from various spinal
nerves, which are now carried together to some target location. Major plexuses
include the [cervical](/wiki/Cervical_plexus "Cervical plexus"),
[brachial](/wiki/Brachial_plexus "Brachial plexus"),
[lumbar](/wiki/Lumbar_plexus "Lumbar plexus"), and
[sacral](/wiki/Sacral_plexus "Sacral plexus") plexuses.

## Regional
nerves[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Spinal_nerve&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Regional nerves")]

Further information: [Spinal cord § Spinal cord
segments](/wiki/Spinal_cord#Spinal_cord_segments "Spinal cord")

### Cervical
nerves[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Spinal_nerve&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Cervical nerves")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Gray795.png/220px-
Gray795.png)](/wiki/File:Gray795.png)

[](/wiki/File:Gray795.png "Enlarge")

Cervical nerves

The cervical nerves are the spinal nerves from the cervical vertebrae in the
[cervical segment](/wiki/Spinal_cord#Spinal_cord_segments "Spinal cord") of
the spinal cord. Although there are seven cervical vertebrae (C1-C7), there
are eight cervical nerves [C1](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_1 "Cervical spinal
nerve 1")–[C8](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_8 "Cervical spinal nerve 8"). All
cervical nerves except C8 emerge above their corresponding vertebrae, while
the C8 nerve emerges below the C7 vertebra. Elsewhere in the spine, the nerve
emerges below the vertebra with the same name.

The posterior distribution includes the [suboccipital
nerve](/wiki/Suboccipital_nerve "Suboccipital nerve") (C1), the [greater
occipital nerve](/wiki/Greater_occipital_nerve "Greater occipital nerve") (C2)
and the [third occipital nerve](/wiki/Third_occipital_nerve "Third occipital
nerve") (C3). The anterior distribution includes the [cervical
plexus](/wiki/Cervical_plexus "Cervical plexus") (C1-C4) and [brachial
plexus](/wiki/Brachial_plexus "Brachial plexus") (C5-T1).

The cervical nerves innervate the [sternohyoid](/wiki/Sternohyoid_muscle
"Sternohyoid muscle"), [sternothyroid](/wiki/Sternothyroid_muscle
"Sternothyroid muscle") and [omohyoid muscles](/wiki/Omohyoid_muscle "Omohyoid
muscle").

A loop of nerves called [ansa cervicalis](/wiki/Ansa_cervicalis "Ansa
cervicalis") is part of the cervical plexus.

### Thoracic
nerves[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Spinal_nerve&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Thoracic nerves")]

The thoracic nerves are the twelve spinal nerves emerging from the thoracic
vertebrae. Each thoracic nerve T1 -T12 originates from below each
corresponding [thoracic vertebra](/wiki/Thoracic_vertebra "Thoracic
vertebra"). Branches also exit the spine and go directly to the [paravertebral
ganglia](/wiki/Paravertebral_ganglia "Paravertebral ganglia") of the
[autonomic nervous system](/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system "Autonomic nervous
system") where they are involved in the functions of organs and glands in the
head, neck, thorax and abdomen.

Anterior divisions: The [intercostal nerves](/wiki/Intercostal_nerves
"Intercostal nerves") come from thoracic nerves T1-T11, and run between the
ribs. At T2 and T3, further branches form the [intercostobrachial
nerve](/wiki/Intercostobrachial_nerve "Intercostobrachial nerve"). The
[subcostal nerve](/wiki/Subcostal_nerve "Subcostal nerve") comes from nerve
T12, and runs below the twelfth rib.

Posterior divisions: The medial branches (ramus medialis) of the posterior
branches of the upper six thoracic nerves run between the [semispinalis
dorsi](/wiki/Semispinalis_dorsi "Semispinalis dorsi") and
[multifidus](/wiki/Multifidus "Multifidus"), which they supply; they then
pierce the [rhomboid](/wiki/Rhomboid_muscle "Rhomboid muscle") and [trapezius
muscles](/wiki/Trapezius_muscle "Trapezius muscle"), and reach the skin by the
sides of the spinous processes. This sensitive branch is called the medial
cutaneous ramus.

The medial branches of the lower six are distributed chiefly to the multifidus
and [longissimus dorsi](/wiki/Longissimus_dorsi "Longissimus dorsi"),
occasionally they give off filaments to the skin near the middle line. This
sensitive branch is called the posterior cutaneous ramus.

### Lumbar nerves[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Spinal_nerve&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Lumbar nerves")]

Further information: [List of lumbar nerves](/wiki/List_of_lumbar_nerves "List
of lumbar nerves")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Gray823.png/220px-
Gray823.png)](/wiki/File:Gray823.png)

[](/wiki/File:Gray823.png "Enlarge")

Lumbar plexus and branches

The lumbar nerves are the five spinal nerves emerging from the lumbar
vertebrae. They are divided into posterior and anterior divisions.

**Posterior divisions** : The medial branches of the posterior divisions of
the lumbar nerves run close to the articular processes of the vertebrae and
end in the [multifidus muscle](/wiki/Multifidus_muscle "Multifidus muscle").

The laterals supply the [erector spinae muscles](/wiki/Erector_spinae_muscles
"Erector spinae muscles").

The upper three give off cutaneous nerves which pierce the aponeurosis of the
[latissimus dorsi](/wiki/Latissimus_dorsi "Latissimus dorsi") at the lateral
border of the erector spinae muscles, and descend across the posterior part of
the [iliac crest](/wiki/Iliac_crest "Iliac crest") to the skin of the
[buttock](/wiki/Buttock "Buttock"), some of their twigs running as far as the
level of the [greater trochanter](/wiki/Greater_trochanter "Greater
trochanter").

**Anterior divisions** : The anterior divisions of the lumbar nerves (rami
anteriores) increase in size from above downward. They are joined, near their
origins, by [gray rami communicantes](/wiki/Gray_rami_communicantes "Gray rami
communicantes") from the [lumbar ganglia](/wiki/Lumbar_ganglia "Lumbar
ganglia") of the [sympathetic trunk](/wiki/Sympathetic_trunk "Sympathetic
trunk"). These rami consist of long, slender branches which accompany the
[lumbar arteries](/wiki/Lumbar_arteries "Lumbar arteries") around the sides of
the vertebral bodies, beneath the [psoas major](/wiki/Psoas_major "Psoas
major"). Their arrangement is somewhat irregular: one ganglion may give rami
to two lumbar nerves, or one lumbar nerve may receive rami from two
[ganglia](/wiki/Ganglia "Ganglia").

The first and second, and sometimes the third and fourth lumbar nerves are
each connected with the lumbar part of the sympathetic trunk by a [white ramus
communicans](/wiki/White_ramus_communicans "White ramus communicans").

The nerves pass obliquely outward behind the psoas major, or between its
[fasciculi](/wiki/Muscle_fascicle "Muscle fascicle"), distributing filaments
to it and the [quadratus lumborum](/wiki/Quadratus_lumborum "Quadratus
lumborum").

The first three and the greater part of the fourth are connected together in
this situation by anastomotic loops, and form the [lumbar
plexus](/wiki/Lumbar_plexus "Lumbar plexus").

The smaller part of the fourth joins with the fifth to form the [lumbosacral
trunk](/wiki/Lumbosacral_trunk "Lumbosacral trunk"), which assists in the
formation of the [sacral plexus](/wiki/Sacral_plexus "Sacral plexus"). The
fourth nerve is named the [furcal
nerve](/w/index.php?title=Furcal_nerve&action=edit&redlink=1 "Furcal nerve
\(page does not exist\)"), from the fact that it is subdivided between the two
plexuses.

### Sacral nerves[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Spinal_nerve&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Sacral nerves")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Gray828.png/220px-
Gray828.png)](/wiki/File:Gray828.png)

[](/wiki/File:Gray828.png "Enlarge")

Plan of sacral and pudendal plexuses

The **sacral nerves** are the five pairs of spinal nerves which exit the
[sacrum](/wiki/Sacrum "Sacrum") at the lower end of the [vertebral
column](/wiki/Human_vertebral_column "Human vertebral column"). The roots of
these nerves begin inside the vertebral column at the level of the [L1
vertebra](/wiki/L1_vertebra "L1 vertebra"), where the [cauda
equina](/wiki/Cauda_equina "Cauda equina") begins, and then descend into the
sacrum.[2][3]

There are five paired sacral nerves, half of them arising through the sacrum
on the left side and the other half on the right side. Each nerve emerges in
two divisions: one division through the [anterior sacral
foramina](/wiki/Anterior_sacral_foramina "Anterior sacral foramina") and the
other division through the [posterior sacral
foramina](/wiki/Posterior_sacral_foramina "Posterior sacral foramina").[4]

The nerves divide into branches and the branches from different nerves join
with one another, some of them also joining with lumbar or coccygeal nerve
branches. These anastomoses of nerves form the [sacral
plexus](/wiki/Sacral_plexus "Sacral plexus") and the [lumbosacral
plexus](/wiki/Lumbosacral_plexus "Lumbosacral plexus"). The branches of these
plexus give rise to nerves that supply much of the [hip](/wiki/Hip "Hip"),
[thigh](/wiki/Thigh "Thigh"), [leg](/wiki/Leg "Leg") and [foot](/wiki/Foot
"Foot").[5][6]

The sacral nerves have both [afferent](/wiki/Afferent_nerve_fiber "Afferent
nerve fiber") and [efferent fibers](/wiki/Efferent_fibers "Efferent fibers"),
thus they are responsible for part of the [sensory
perception](/wiki/Sensory_perception "Sensory perception") and the movements
of the lower extremities of the human body. From the S2, S3 and S4 arise the
pudendal nerve and parasympathetic fibers whose electrical potential supply
the [descending colon](/wiki/Descending_colon "Descending colon") and
[rectum](/wiki/Rectum "Rectum"), [urinary bladder](/wiki/Urinary_bladder
"Urinary bladder") and [genital organs](/wiki/Genital_organs "Genital
organs"). These pathways have both afferent and efferent fibers and, this way,
they are responsible for conduction of sensory information from these pelvic
organs to the [central nervous system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system "Central
nervous system") (CNS) and motor impulses from the CNS to the pelvis that
control the movements of these pelvic organs.[7]

### Coccygeal
nerve[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Spinal_nerve&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Coccygeal nerve")]

The coccygeal nerve is the 31st pair of spinal nerves. It arises from the
conus medullaris, and its anterior root helps form the [coccygeal
plexus](/wiki/Coccygeal_plexus "Coccygeal plexus"). It does not divide into a
medial and lateral branch. It is distributed to the skin over the back of the
[coccyx](/wiki/Coccyx "Coccyx").

## Function[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Spinal_nerve&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Function")]

Gray802.png)](/wiki/File:Gray802.png)

[](/wiki/File:Gray802.png "Enlarge")

Areas of distribution of the cutaneous branches of the posterior divisions of
the spinal nerves. The areas of the medial branches are in black, those of the
lateral in red

**Actions of thespinal nerves** [edit](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Actions_by_spinal_nerves&action=edit) Level | Motor function  
---|---  
[C1](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_1 "Cervical spinal nerve 1")–[C6](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_6 "Cervical spinal nerve 6") | [Neck](/wiki/Neck "Neck") [flexors](/wiki/Flexor "Flexor")  
[C1](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_1 "Cervical spinal nerve 1")–[T1](/wiki/Thoracic_spinal_nerve_1 "Thoracic spinal nerve 1") | [Neck](/wiki/Neck "Neck") [extensors](/wiki/Extensor "Extensor")  
[C3](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_3 "Cervical spinal nerve 3"), [C4](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_4 "Cervical spinal nerve 4"), [C5](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_5 "Cervical spinal nerve 5") | Supply [diaphragm](/wiki/Diaphragm_\(anatomy\) "Diaphragm \(anatomy\)") (mostly [C4](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_4 "Cervical spinal nerve 4"))  
[C5](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_5 "Cervical spinal nerve 5"), [C6](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_6 "Cervical spinal nerve 6") | Move [shoulder](/wiki/Shoulder "Shoulder"), raise [arm](/wiki/Arm "Arm") ([deltoid](/wiki/Deltoid_muscle "Deltoid muscle")); flex elbow ([biceps](/wiki/Biceps "Biceps"))  
[C6](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_6 "Cervical spinal nerve 6") | externally rotate ([supinate](/wiki/Supinate "Supinate")) the arm  
[C6](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_6 "Cervical spinal nerve 6"), [C7](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_7 "Cervical spinal nerve 7") | [Extend](/wiki/Extension_\(kinesiology\) "Extension \(kinesiology\)") [elbow](/wiki/Elbow-joint "Elbow-joint") and [wrist](/wiki/Wrist "Wrist") ([triceps](/wiki/Triceps_brachii_muscle "Triceps brachii muscle") and wrist [extensors](/wiki/Extensor "Extensor")); [pronate](/wiki/Pronate "Pronate") wrist  
[C7](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_7 "Cervical spinal nerve 7"), [C8](/wiki/Cervical_spinal_nerve_8 "Cervical spinal nerve 8") | Flex wrist; supply small muscles of the [hand](/wiki/Hand "Hand")  
[T1](/wiki/Thoracic_spinal_nerve_1 "Thoracic spinal nerve 1")–[T6](/wiki/Thoracic_spinal_nerve_6 "Thoracic spinal nerve 6") | [Intercostals](/wiki/Intercostal_muscle "Intercostal muscle") and [trunk](/wiki/Torso "Torso") above the [waist](/wiki/Waist "Waist")  
[T7](/wiki/Thoracic_spinal_nerve_7 "Thoracic spinal nerve 7")–[L1](/wiki/Lumbar_spinal_nerve_1 "Lumbar spinal nerve 1") | [Abdominal](/wiki/Abdomen "Abdomen") muscles  
[L1](/wiki/Lumbar_spinal_nerve_1 "Lumbar spinal nerve 1")–[L4](/wiki/Lumbar_spinal_nerve_4 "Lumbar spinal nerve 4") | Flex [thigh](/wiki/Thigh "Thigh")  
[L2](/wiki/Lumbar_spinal_nerve_2 "Lumbar spinal nerve 2"), [L3](/wiki/Lumbar_spinal_nerve_3 "Lumbar spinal nerve 3"), [L4](/wiki/Lumbar_spinal_nerve_4 "Lumbar spinal nerve 4") | [Adduct](/wiki/Adduction "Adduction") thigh; Extend [leg](/wiki/Human_leg "Human leg") at the [knee](/wiki/Knee "Knee") ([quadriceps femoris](/wiki/Quadriceps_femoris "Quadriceps femoris"))  
[L4](/wiki/Lumbar_spinal_nerve_4 "Lumbar spinal nerve 4"), [L5](/wiki/Lumbar_spinal_nerve_5 "Lumbar spinal nerve 5"), [S1](/wiki/Sacral_spinal_nerve_1 "Sacral spinal nerve 1") | [abduct](/wiki/Abduction_\(kinesiology\) "Abduction \(kinesiology\)") thigh; Flex leg at the knee ([hamstrings](/wiki/Hamstring "Hamstring")); [Dorsiflex](/wiki/Dorsiflexion "Dorsiflexion") [foot](/wiki/Foot "Foot") ([tibialis anterior](/wiki/Tibialis_anterior "Tibialis anterior")); Extend [toes](/wiki/Toe "Toe")  
[L5](/wiki/Lumbar_spinal_nerve_5 "Lumbar spinal nerve 5"), [S1](/wiki/Sacral_spinal_nerve_1 "Sacral spinal nerve 1"), [S2](/wiki/Sacral_spinal_nerve_2 "Sacral spinal nerve 2") | Extend leg at the [hip](/wiki/Hip "Hip") ([gluteus maximus](/wiki/Gluteus_maximus "Gluteus maximus")); flex foot and flex toes  
  
## Clinical
significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Spinal_nerve&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Clinical significance")]

The muscles that one particular spinal root supplies are that nerve's
[myotome](/wiki/Myotome_\(anatomy\) "Myotome \(anatomy\)"), and the
[dermatomes](/wiki/Dermatome_\(anatomy\) "Dermatome \(anatomy\)") are the
areas of sensory innervation on the skin for each spinal nerve. Lesions of one
or more nerve roots result in typical patterns of neurologic defects ([muscle
weakness](/wiki/Muscle_weakness "Muscle weakness"), abnormal sensation,
changes in reflexes) that allow localization of the responsible lesion.

There are several procedures used in [sacral nerve
stimulation](/wiki/Sacral_nerve_stimulation "Sacral nerve stimulation") for
the treatment of various related disorders.

[Sciatica](/wiki/Sciatica "Sciatica") is generally caused by the compression
of lumbar nerves L4, or L5 or sacral nerves S1, S2, or S3, or by compression
of the sciatic nerve itself.
